J. B. Rainsberger and all the others who participated in my thread a 
few weeks ago:

Now Eclipse 3.0 supports what I was looking for: 
http://sunsite.informatik.rwth-aachen.de/eclipse/downloads/drops/R-
3.0-200406251208/eclipse-news-part7-R3.html

Take a look at header "JUnit Integration": "JUnit now supports 
decorating an individual test for a test run. This is done by 
implementing a public static setUpTest(Test) method in your TestCase 
class ..."

I had not yet the time to test your solution. Now there is a 
solution by Eclipse.

By the way, I want to use it to override setUp(). It needs to create 
an entity in the database because all other tests are depending on 
that entity in the database. I do this because I want to have as few 
preconditions for our tests as possible. But lets not dig deeper in 
this, because I will not follow this discussion very much longer.

Rainsberger, you write you consider using tearDown() a smell. We use 
this method for our persistance layer tests. For each entity (like 
Article, Supplier and so on) we have a test case class with methods 
like testCreateArticle, testUpdateArticle, testDeleteArticle, 
testGetArticleById, testArticleIdValidation and so on. The tearDown
() deletes the created entities. So it is not just something like 
instanceVariable = null. I don't consider tearDown() as code smell.
